ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Wow, I learned A TON about Southeastern Europe. I walk away with a much better understanding of the former Yugoslavia and exactly what led to its breakup.
I learned about a totally new region of the world and different frameworks for understanding democratic transition.
This is an absolutely fascinating course covering necessary topics of understanding like democratic transitions, while deeply diving into the Balkan region.
I learned how to think critically about history and how to apply political theories to that history.

We gained an in-depth understanding of the troubles faced by Eastern Europe during and after the transition out of communism, including the role of political institutions and citizens in shaping the course of history which is very translatable to other circumstances.
I learned a lot about Balkan history, which is an area of the world I am fascinated by. I also improved my research skills.
I loved this course because she made the material easy to consume and also very interesting. I was eager to come to class and do the readings!
I learned a lot about how communist regimes struggled, and still do, to transition to just, fair, uncorrupt governments in the Balkans.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Amazing professor, super interesting content. For the first time I actually did the optional readings for a class just because it was that interesting.
The course is really engaging, and the readings are digestible.
A brilliant course with great variance in assignments, topics discussed, and outcomes.

Strengths: Professor Aldrich is an amazing   Instructor and always made everyone feel comfortable to talk in class. She took feedback from students very seriously and shaped the class around what worked best for us. 

Weakness: sometimes there was a lot of reading for each week and I Occasionally  found it difficult to comprehend. I got better at reading these types of articles as the class went on!
I really liked the course, honestly very little to improve
All around great with the discussion notes, the modules keep everything organized, and the readings help with the seminar. Weakness the 9 am start time
I thought some of the readings were a little too dense to follow and then weren't followed by enough discussion in class to completely digest what was happening.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This was excellent for an online seminar.
Shared discussion doc was really helpful!

I thought that the seminar was great! I think the debate assignments translated well and the transition into using a blog format for reading responses was very creative and useful to get more practice with working from the backend of a site.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: 100%, far and away the best class I've taken in the political science department, if not Yale.
Yes! The topic is really interesting and I think that anyone interest in foreign policy, or political theory would be interested in this course.
Absolutely.
yes
Take this class! Professor Aldrich is the best professor at Yale
Yes! If you are interested in the region this is a great course to take. I loved watching all the films and really got a lot out of them.
Absolutely. It is a niche course, but even if you are not interested in Balkan history, the theoretical exploration of democratization is relevant throughout.
yes!
Absolutely! I enjoyed the course, I would have enjoyed it more in a non-COVID year. Pandemic burnout made it very difficult to participate and remain as engaged as I would have liked in my classes.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Recorded lectures, debates, readings, live lectures
We met over zoom once a week.
